data.text: Any of various deciduous trees of the genus Ulmus, characteristically having arching or curving branches, serrate leaves with asymmetric bases, and small winged fruit.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The wood of one of these trees.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The common name for species of Ulmus (which see), mostly large trees, some common in cultivation for shade and ornament, for which the majestic height and the wide-spreading and gracefully curving branches of the principal kinds admirably adapt them.

Of other varieties of elm (comprising some trees more or less closely related to the elm and a few belonging to different families but somewhat resembling elms: those given below are among the most important.
The wing-elm or winged elm. See <internalXref urlencoded="wahoo">wahoo</internalXref>,.
The winged elm, Ulmus alata, so called in Florida and Arkansas.

Ulmus serotina, a tree of limited distribution on limestone hills and river-banks in southern Kentucky and northern Alabama and Georgia, only recently distinguished from U. fulva, from which it differs in its much smaller fruit, in the absence of mucilage in the inner bark, and in other respects. The wood is reddish in color.

A tree of the genus Ulmus, of several species, much used as a shade tree, particularly in America. The English elm is <spn>Ulmus campestris</spn>; the common American or white elm is <spn>U. Americana</spn>; the slippery or red elm, <spn>U. fulva</spn>.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: one of several species of beetles (esp. <spn>Galeruca calmariensis</spn>), which feed on the leaves of the elm.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: one of several species of beetles of which the larvæ bore into the wood or under the bark of the elm (esp. <spn>Saperda tridentata</spn>).
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
